dt: {bc}an authorization granted by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration during a public health emergency that allows for the use of a drug or other medical product prior to its full approval

dt.t: Under section 564 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act), when the Secretary of HHS declares that an {wi}emergency use authorization{/wi} is appropriate, FDA may authorize unapproved medical products or unapproved uses of approved medical products to be used in an emergency …

Especially during a shortage, much of the red tape needs to be cut away, much as formal review processes for new vaccines and drugs gave way to {wi}Emergency Use Authorizations{/wi} during the pandemic.
The U.S. Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday granted {wi}emergency use authorization{/wi} for the Pfizer booster for this age group …

shortdef: an authorization granted by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration during a public health emergency that allows for the use of a drug or other medical product prior to its full approval —called also EUA

dt: {bc}authorization (as by an insurer) that is required prior to performance of a health-care service (such as a surgery or prescription of a drug)

dt.t: Hospital leaders expect the new managed care companies to demand {wi}pre-authorization{/wi} for many treatments, which could lead to fewer reimbursements and more hospital staff time devoted to hashing out billing differences.
{wi}Preauthorization{/wi} requires doctors, like me, to spend time we do not have dealing with insurance companies to get the medicine our patients so desperately need.

shortdef: prior authorization; especially : authorization (as by an insurer) that is required prior to performance of a health-care service (such as a surgery or prescription of a drug)
